properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero today. Conditions will improve gradually late today. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-16T06:24:16-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of freezing rain giving 2 to 4 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T18:59:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T09:59:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4200907248.2019
Area: Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A bitterly cold Arctic air mass is keeping a firm grip on far Northern Ontario. Extreme cold wind chills near or below minus 45 are occurring this morning. These extreme cold wind chills will moderate this afternoon but may return over portions of the area tonight into Monday morning. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T19:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T10:10:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2441593946.2019
Area: Attawapiskat, Fort Severn, Peawanuck, Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries at times heavy and a risk of snowsqualls are expected to develop overnight tonight and persist on Monday. Total snowfall: locally up to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Time span: overnight tonight until early Monday evening. Remarks: A strong westerly flow of cold air over the Gulf of St. Lawrence will cause flurries at times heavy to develop overnight tonight. Blowing snow over exposed areas is likely and there is a possibility of the development of snowsqualls giving heavy snow and poor visibility. These conditions will diminish late Monday and Monday night as a ridge of high pressure approaches. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-16T06:23:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T14:24:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3753316479.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mixture freezing precipitation and rain is expected. Locations: Upper Lake Melville and Norman Bay to Lodge Bay. Total rainfall: up to 5 mm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h along the coast. Time span: continuing until tonight. Remarks: Ice pellets or freezing rain will change to rain today, before tapering to drizzle or freezing drizzle this evening. The precipitation will be accompanied by strong easterly winds along the coast. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-15T23:03:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T14:28:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0793919096.2019
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Upper Lake Melville

Remarks: Snow will change through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain today, before tapering to drizzle or freezing drizzle this evening. The precipitation will be accompanied by strong easterly winds along the coast. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snow and ice pellet accumulations: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h tonight into Monday. Locations: Churchill Falls and Churchill Valley. Time span: continuing until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to change to ice pellets or freezing rain during the day and possibly to rain by this evening. Precipitation will transition back to snow tonight. Strong northwesterly winds are also expected to develop tonight, resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. The blowing snow will persist into Monday night. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High water levels expected today. Location: South shore of Nova Scotia. Time span: During the high tide near noon today. Large waves with rough and pounding surf enhanced by storm surge can be expected along the Atlantic coast during high tide today, and may cause some minor flooding along the coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Locations: Nain, Natuashish, Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: continuing until Monday night. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will continue through tonight and Monday in the Nain and Natuashish areas, but is expected to mix with rain in the Hopedale area. Strengthening easterly winds will accompany the snow, resulting in poor visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will begin to ease overnight tonight. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

Location: Magdalen Islands Maximum wind gusts: up to 100 km/h Time span: tonight through Monday Remarks: Strong westerly winds will develop tonight with gusts reaching as high as 90 km/h by Monday morning. Winds are currently expected to diminish late Monday night. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm except locally 30 cm or more in snow squalls. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Hawke's Bay.
